Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Second Arterial Conduit Use in Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted using a state-maintained clinical registry

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients undergoing primary, isolated multi-vessel CABG with the left internal thoracic artery between 2006 and 2011.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received a second arterial conduit (right internal thoracic artery or radial artery), while the control group received a venous conduit.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effect of using a second arterial conduit compared to a venous conduit.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was all-cause mortality at 7 years.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 5,866 patients received a second arterial conduit, and 53,566 received a venous conduit.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group had significantly lower mortality (13.1% vs. 10.6%; HR 0.79, 95% CI 0.72–0.87) and reduced risks of myocardial infarction (HR 0.78, 95% CI 0.70–0.87) and repeat revascularization (HR 0.82, 95% CI 0.76–0.88).

Harms.evidence: Right internal thoracic artery grafts had similar mortality to radial artery grafts but increased sternal wound infection risk (risk difference 1.07%, 95% CI 0.15%–2.07%).
